content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, with a significant impact on children and school absenteeism. The prevalence of asthma has increased over the years, especially among low-income families and women. The prevalence of asthma is higher in women than in men, with a greater impact on low-income families. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks, with higher death rates among African Americans compared to Caucasians. Asthma costs the United States over $12 billion annually. Asthma disproportionately affects African Americans, with a higher death rate among African American children. Exercise can improve the well-being of children with asthma and help them develop lifelong habits of physical activity. Grants for asthma-related activities in low-income communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants for projects in low-income communities focusing on screenings, education, and workshops related to asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems. The screenings and referrals will be conducted to ensure early detection and appropriate care for individuals in these communities. The Secretary will ensure comprehensive screenings and referrals for asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems in various settings including medical facilities, schools, community centers, and government offices. The Secretary will provide information and education on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems in various community settings, tailored to the language and cultural context of the individuals. This includes increasing understanding of symptoms. The Secretary will provide information and education on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems in various community settings, tailored to the language and cultural context of the individuals. This includes increasing understanding of symptoms, preventing, monitoring, and managing conditions, and the importance of physical activities for asthmatic children. The Secretary will evaluate projects under subsection (a) to determine the impact on individuals in preventing and managing asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems. This includes assessing the number of children receiving screenings and referrals, as well as the effect on physical activities for asthmatic children. The projects under evaluation focus on screenings, referrals, and education for asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Grants require involvement of local community-based organizations in project implementation. The Secretary may make a grant if an application is submitted in the required form and contains necessary information. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for subsequent years. SEC. 4. NATIONAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN TO PROVIDE ASTHMA-RELATED INFORMATION. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, prioritizing children. The campaign must focus on prevention and management of these conditions and highlight available community programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, prioritizing children. The campaign must focus on prevention and management of these conditions, highlight available community programs, and be culturally appropriate. Authorization of appropriations is set at $600,000 for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. SEC. 5. TAX CREDIT FOR DONATIONS OF PEST CONTROL AND CLIMATE CONTROL SERVICES. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section for a tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services. For taxpayers providing pest control or climate control services, a donation credit of 10% of costs incurred in providing qualified services is available. Qualified services include those provided for free in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties. Pest control and climate control services are eligible for a donation credit of 10% of costs incurred if provided for free in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties with occupants below 200% of the poverty line. Services must be part of a good faith effort and verified as prescribed by the Secretary. The term 'pest control and climate control services' refers to eliminating pests and improving ventilation or temperature control. Taxpayers providing these services can receive a donation credit under certain conditions. The tax code is amended to include a new paragraph regarding donation credits for taxpayers providing pest control or climate control services. Unused credits cannot be carried back before January 1, 2000. The tax code allows donation credits for pest control or climate control services, with unused credits not eligible for carryback before January 1, 2000. The tax code allows donation credits for pest control and climate control services, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Additionally, there is a provision for research on the relationship between air pollutants and asthma-related problems. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Clinical research will prioritize individuals for clinical evaluations. Opportunities for clinical evaluations are available for individuals residing in low-income communities. These individuals must have a family income at or below 200 percent of the poverty line. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will work with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee to identify federal asthma programs, develop a federal response plan, and improve coordination of asthma-related activities. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will have a representative on the committee. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will have a representative on the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee. $5,000,000 from NIH funds will be allocated to the program for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. SEC. 8. COMPILATION OF DATA BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. They also compile and publish data on the prevalence of children with asthma in each state and childhood mortality rates associated with asthma nationally and in each state.
